subject: News from HBO
event:
I have some exciting news to share.

(But please, guys and gals, don't get TOO excited.  This is what it is, and so far that's all it is, so don't make any assumptions).

HBO has just exercised its option, and purchased the television rights to A GAME OF THRONES.

For those of you who don't know Hollywood, an option gives a production company the right to buy a property (a book, a screenplay, whatever) at a certain agreed-upon price for a certain period of time (a year, six months, whatever).  When that time runs out, they can let the option lapse, renew the option, or exercise the option and buy the property.  The last is what HBO has just done.

What they have NOT done is greenlight the project.  A GAME OF THRONES remains in development.  They're still budgeting, still looking at locations (Spain and the Czech Republic at present, I hear).  No decision has been reached, so any celebration would be premature.  In Hollywood it is always best not to assume something is going to happen until it actually happens.  

Even so... this is a very encouraging sign, and one that suggests a continued high level of enthusiasm and commitment for A GAME OF THRONES at HBO.

So keep your fingers crossed.

comments.article: Reason enough to celebrate for me!

Hells yeah. HBO is the only company I'd trust to do it right.

Did anyone watch The Comeback? Was I the only person who loved it?


-Ari
http://airtheremin.wordpress.com

comments.upictitle: blame me for the rocks and baby bones.: beside the acacias freshly in bloom
comments.article: my very first thought. FIREFLYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY.

I am still undecided how I feel about this project.  I've seen television (other than the Beeb) and movies make mincemeat of many of my most beloved books.  But if this gets made, I will watch it, and will more than likely buy it if/when it appears of DVD.  Aside from all that, I'm very pleased to hear your work is getting the recognition it deserves.  I wish you well in this, and hope the writing on DANCE is going well.
This has nothing to do with your comment. I just had to say that I LOVE your icon!  :)

comments.upictitle: J3n the Destruct0r: OH HAI I LIEK ABORTIONS
comments.article: Cooooooooooool!

I hope it goes smooth as silk.

You deserve it. :)
Good news, George. Just make sure you get final veto rights so they don't go and make the plot skip the tracks so badly that you can see the skid marks. 'Dem shifty televisionators!
Yes!  Congrats!  We'll hope it happens sooner rather than later.

This is awesome news! I hope it all works out, and those of us who are completely in love with your series can watch it done by the masters! After watching Deadwood, Rome, and Carvinale, I only have praise for "costume" dramas done by HBO.
I really hope they choose to go on with the project!!! *keeps her fingers crossed too*
This certainly brightened my evening!

comments.upictitle: Rum, Sodomy, and the Lash: Pick Two: ape-book
comments.article: Still too soon to send them a script?

Carnivale, Rome, Deadwood and aSoIaF all have something in common...

At least this time HBO will have a legitimate reason for leaving a series unfinished. Then again, they're obviously used to the 'prima-donna approach' of an author not giving one whit about the timely production of his work.

This situation DOES beg the question of what WILL the response be when asked about the status of aDwD by someone who's invested millions into a property and the response is 'well y'see, football season and DragonCon and off to Europe look at these dolls!'.

comments.article: Just the mere thought of ASOIAF on HBO makes me giddy. *thinks happy thoughts and green lights*

Admittedly it makes me happy too, the problem is, it's not quite happy enough to overcome the frustration with GRRM's total lack of commitment to finishing the series.

I realize that someone's going to attempt to have the same argument with me as last time, but for God's sake, at least he could PRETEND that he's actually trying to finish it.

Maybe he'll care enough about his relationship with HBO that it'll provide him a bit of incentive to finish it up, because he damned sure doesn't care about his creation itself.

So, in short, 'grats GRRM, I guess?
